questions.text: Which demographic is more likely to experience manic episodes in bipolar I disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Women

  • This is incorrect; women are more likely to experience depressive episodes, not manic ones.

Option B: Men

  • This is the correct answer. The text indicates that manic episodes are more common in men.

Option C: Adolescents

  • This is incorrect; while adolescents can experience bipolar disorder, the text specifies that manic episodes are more prevalent in men overall.

Option D: Elderly individuals

  • This is incorrect; adults are specifically more likely to experience manic episodes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Maniac episodes are more common in men.

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus and left insula

questions.text: Which brain regions have shown consistent structural findings in individuals with bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Neuroanatomical changes in Bipolar disorder:

  • Gray Matter Variations: Reported in striatum, thalamus, amygdala, hippocampus, and pituitary; findings are inconsistent. Meta-analysis found no strong support for morphological differences.
  • Consistent Areas: Notable changes in inferior frontal gyrus, left insula, cerebellum, and left orbitofrontal gyrus linked to emotional regulation and executive function. Increased thickness suggests compensatory changes rather than etiological factors.
  • Functional Imaging Findings: Fewer fMRI/PET studies; increased activation in superior and medial frontal cortex, and insula; decreased activation in amygdala, basal ganglion, and limbic system during cognitive/emotional tasks.

Option A: Striatum and thalamus:

While these areas are of interest, studies have reported conflicting results regarding structural differences in these regions among bipolar patients.

Option B: Inferior frontal gyrus and left insula:

Correct choice. These regions consistently show structural differences in bipolar patients and first-degree relatives, indicating their involvement in emotional regulation and executive function.

Option C: Hippocampus and pituitary:

Findings in the hippocampus are inconsistent, and the pituitary gland has not been shown to have significant structural differences in bipolar disorder.

Option D: Amygdala and cerebellum:

Although the amygdala is linked to emotional processing, findings regarding structural changes are not consistent. The cerebellum's role in bipolar disorder is still being explored.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Neuroanatomical changes in Bipolar disorder: increased activation in superior and medial frontal cortex, and insula; decreased activation in amygdala, basal ganglion, and limbic system during cognitive/emotional tasks.

questions.text: Which inflammatory marker has been found to be elevated in bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Neurochemical changes in Bipolar disorder:

  • Inflammatory Markers: Elevated interleukin-6 in bipolar patients, especially during adolescence; decreases in adulthood.
  • Neurochemical Findings: Alterations in brain-derived neurotrophic factor may predict lithium responsiveness. Preliminary studies show oxidative stress abnormalities related to lithium response.
  • HPA Axis Assessment: Dysregulated system indicated by increased ACTH and cortisol levels, occurring after symptoms manifest, suggesting a response to the disorder.

Option A: Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ): While it is an important cytokine, it is not specifically associated with bipolar disorder in the same way IL-6 is.

Option B: C-reactive protein (CRP): CRP indicates systemic inflammation, but its connection to bipolar disorder is less direct compared to IL-6.

Option C: Interleukin-6 (IL-6): IL-6 is notably elevated in bipolar patients, especially during adolescence, indicating its potential role in the disorder's pathophysiology.

Option D: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α): While it plays a role in inflammation, evidence linking TNF-α specifically to bipolar disorder is not as strong as for IL-6.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Interleukin-6 (IL-6) is found to be elevated in bipolar disorder

questions.text: How do cognitive deficits in bipolar disorder compare to those in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Psychology of Bipolar disorder:

  • Psychological studies highlight cognitive deficits in bipolar disorder, particularly in executive functioning and verbal memory.
  • Response inhibition, the ability to suppress impulsive reactions, is notably deficient in bipolar patients and first-degree relatives.
  • Executive function deficits also include impulsivity and risk-taking behaviour.
  • Cognitive deficits may indicate a broader spectrum of disorders linked by psychotic symptoms.

Option A: More severe and recognized earlier: Cognitive deficits in bipolar disorder are often less severe compared to schizophrenia.

Option B: Less severe and recognized later: Cognitive deficits in schizophrenia tend to be more severe than those in bipolar disorder and are less likely to be identified before the disorder appears.

Option C: More specific to auditory processing: This is not accurate; the cognitive deficits discussed do not specifically target auditory processing.

Option D: Less related to impulsivity: Impulsivity is a significant concern in bipolar disorder, making this option incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cognitive deficits in bipolar disorder are less severe and appear late in comparison to those with schizophrenia.

questions.text: How does the inter episode interval change as bipolar disorder progresses?
questions.solution:
Course of Bipolar disorder:

  • The onset of bipolar I disorder often follows an initial diagnosis of major depressive disorder, with 5-10% of patients developing manic episodes after several years.
  • Most cases begin with depression, and about 90% of individuals with a manic episode will experience another.
  • Untreated manic episodes typically last around 3 months, while depressive episodes resemble those of depressive disorders.
  • Bipolar II disorder is chronic, requiring long-term treatment, and patients generally maintain their diagnosis over time.

Option A: It always decreases: This is misleading; it does not continuously decrease indefinitely.

Option B: It becomes longer with age: This is not true; stabilization occurs rather than a clear lengthening.

Option C: It stabilizes after five episodes: After around five episodes, the interval between episodes often stabilizes at 6 to 9 months.

Option D: It varies randomly: While some variation exists, a pattern of stabilization is observed in most cases.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Most cases begin with depression, and about 90% of individuals with a manic episode will experience another

questions.text: Which factor is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with bipolar I disorder?
questions.solution:
Prognosis of Bipolar disorder

  • Patients with bipolar I disorder generally have a poorer prognosis than those with major depressive disorder.
  • Approximately 40-50% may experience a second manic episode within 2 years.
  • Lithium prophylaxis helps, but only 50-60% achieve significant symptom control.
  • After long-term follow-up, about 10% remain chronically ill.
  • Poor prognostic indicators include: male gender, poor occupational status, and the presence of psychotic or depressive features.
  • Short manic episodes and few coexisting psychiatric issues predict better outcomes

Option A: Advanced age of onset: This is typically associated with a better prognosis, not worse.

Option B: Short duration of manic episodes: This generally predicts a better outcome, so it's not linked to poor prognosis.

Option C: Male gender: Correct choice. Studies have shown that male gender can be a factor contributing to a poorer prognosis.

Option D: Few coexisting psychiatric problems: This is associated with a better prognosis, not poor outcomes.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Poor prognostic indicators include: male gender, poor occupational status, and the presence of psychotic or depressive features.

questions.text: What cognitive symptom is often observed in patients experiencing a manic episode?
questions.solution:
• Manic episodes in bipolar disorder are characterized by a distinct set of symptoms that impact mood, cognition, and behaviour.
  • Patients often exhibit mood-congruent delusions, which focus on themes of grandeur, wealth, or extraordinary abilities. These delusions can manifest as a belief in possessing special powers or playing significant roles in important events.
  • Mood-incongruent delusions, such as paranoia, are less common but can occur.
  • Cognitive symptoms include rapid and disorganized thought patterns, often referred to as "flight of ideas" While patients may seem mentally agile, their thoughts can become incoherent, leading to challenges in communication.
  • This disorganized thinking may impair judgment, prompting impulsive decisions that can result in financial ruin, risky behaviours, and strained relationships.
  • Insight into their condition is often lacking; many manic patients believe their elevated mood enhances their abilities and may not recognize the seriousness of their disorder.
  • They may acknowledge feeling "high" but underestimate the potential consequences of their actions.
  • Suicide risk is notably higher during depressive phases rather than in manic or hypomanic episodes, though impulsive behaviour in mania can increase overall risk.

Patients may also engage in substance misuse, such as excessive alcohol consumption, as a form of self-medication.

Option A: Slowed thought processes: This is typical of depression, not mania.

Option B: Flight of ideas: Correct choice. This is a common cognitive symptom where thoughts race and become disorganized.

Option C: Impaired long-term memory: While memory may be affected, this is not a hallmark of mania.

Option D: Rigid thinking: Manic patients often display flexible, albeit chaotic, thought patterns rather than rigidity.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Flight of ideas is observed in patients with mania as a cognitive symptom.

choices.text: They can induce mania or hypomania
They are safe in all phases of the disorder
They do not interact with mood stabilizers

questions.text: What is the primary concern regarding the use of antidepressants in bipolar disorder?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Bipolar Disorder :

  • Hospitalization: Ideal for severe mania, enabling aggressive treatment and managing risky behaviours.
  • Treatment Choices:
    • Medications are primary for bipolar disorder.
    • Psychotherapy complements medication.
  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Includes acute and maintenance phases tailored to mania, hypomania, or depression.
    • Lithium, anticonvulsants, and atypical antipsychotics are commonly used.
  • Medications for Acute Mania:
    • First-line: Lithium, divalproex, olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine, aripiprazole, ziprasidone.
    • Second-line: Carbamazepine, ECT, haloperidol.
    • Not recommended: Gabapentin, topiramate, lamotrigine.
  • Initial Medication Selection: Lithium's slower onset may require adjuncts for immediate effect.
  • Lithium Carbonate:
    • Known as a mood stabilizer (therapeutic level: 0.6-1.2 mEq/L).
    • Less common due to side effects and frequent lab monitoring.
  • Anticonvulsants:
    • Valproate for acute mania, Carbamazepine (FDA-approved in 2004).
  • Antipsychotics: Atypical antipsychotics carry lower side effect risks; weight gain is common.
  • Acute Bipolar Depression:
    • Limited lithium efficacy, lamotrigine is promising but requires slow titration.
  • Antidepressants:
    • Risk of triggering mania; should be used with mood stabilizers, not alone.

Option A: They are always effective: This is false; antidepressants can be ineffective in bipolar disorder.

Option B: They can induce mania or hypomania: Correct. Antidepressants can trigger manic episodes, especially in those with rapid cycling.

Option C: They are safe in all phases of the disorder: This is not true; their safety is questionable in bipolar disorder.

Option D: They do not interact with mood stabilizers: Many antidepressants can interact with mood stabilizers, affecting their efficacy.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: In patients with bipolar disorder, antidepressants can sometimes trigger a switch from depression to mania or hypomania, particularly when used as monotherapy without a mood stabilizer. This phenomenon is known as antidepressant-induced mania and is more common with certain classes of antidepressants, like SSRIs and SNRIs. Because of this risk, antidepressants are usually combined with mood stabilizers (e.g., lithium, valproate) or atypical antipsychotics to minimize the likelihood of a manic episode

questions.text: Which group is generally reported to have a higher prevalence of depression?
questions.solution:
Option A: Adolescents: While prevalence is high in this group, women generally have higher rates overall.

Option B: Men: Men have lower reported rates of depression compared to women.

Option C: Women: Correct. Depression is more common in women than men across cultures.

Option D: Older adults: Not specifically higher; the overall prevalence is lower compared to younger adults.

  • Prevalence:
    • Depression is more common than previously thought and highly debilitating.
    • Meta-analysis (1994-2014):
      • Point prevalence: 12.9%
      • 1-year prevalence: 7.2%
      • Lifetime prevalence: 10.8%
    • Measurement Challenges:
      • True incidence is hard to measure due to:
        • Sample collection methods
        • Definitions of depression
        • Instruments used (self-assessments report higher rates)
      • Demographics:
        • Sex: Higher prevalence in women (14.4%) compared to men (11.5%).
        • Age: Mean onset around 40 years, with significant incidence in adolescents (20% in females).
        • Marital Status: Higher rates in those who are divorced or separated.
      • Socioeconomic Factors:
        • No proven correlation between socioeconomic status and depression.
        • Mixed evidence on urban vs. rural prevalence.
      • Racial/Ethnic Differences:
        • Higher prevalence in White and Native American populations, with challenges in measuring racial and ethnic differences.
      • Stigma:
        • Decreasing stigma may lead to more individuals reporting symptoms.
        • Stigma complicates accurate measurement and understanding of depression.
      • Impact of Technology and Globalization:
        • Has narrowed differences in depression rates between rural and urban areas.
      • Research Findings:
        • Adolescents show higher rates than adults.
        • Increased willingness to report symptoms as stigma decreases.

questions.text: Which factor is thought to decrease neurogenesis according to neurogenesis hypotheses?
questions.solution:
Option A: Physical exercise: Generally promotes neurogenesis.

Option B: Chronic stress: Correct. It is linked to increased glucocorticoid levels, which inhibit neurogenesis.

Option C: Increased social interaction: Typically supportive of mental health and may enhance neurogenesis.

Option D: Adequate sleep: Beneficial for overall brain function and may enhance neurogenesis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Chronic stress can reduce neurogenesis and trigger depression.

questions.text: What happens to the time between depressive episodes as a patient experience more episodes?
questions.solution:
As a patient experiences more episodes, the time between episodes generally decreases.

Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) Course

Onset:

  • 50% of patients show depressive symptoms before the first episode.
  • First episode usually occurs before age 40 for about 50% of patients.
  • Late onset is linked to absence of family history and other disorders.

Duration:

  • Untreated episodes last 6 to 13 months; treated episodes last around 3 months.
  • Early treatment can prevent full depressive episodes.
  • Patients often experience more frequent and longer episodes over time.

Dysthymia:

  • 50% of patients experience symptoms before age 25.
  • Patients often endure symptoms for a decade before seeking help.
  • Early onset increases risk for major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder.
  • Prognosis varies; treatments can improve outcomes.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of ketamine in treating depression?
questions.solution:
Ketamine:

  • Mechanism of Action: Inhibits NMDA receptor, affecting glutamatergic signaling.
  • Administration: Initially available intravenously; positive response within 24 hours.
  • Side Effects: Commonly includes dizziness, headache, and potential dissociative symptoms.
  • Duration of Effects: Lasts 2 to 7 days, necessitating repeated doses; short-term efficacy noted.
  • Abuse Potential: Concerns about psychogenic effects and misuse.

Esketamine:

  • Formulation: Approved as a nasal spray for treatment-resistant depression.
  • Distribution: Available through a restricted system due to abuse risk.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Ketamine blocks NMDA receptors.

choices.text: Being born in a rural area

questions.text: What factor is associated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Risk Factors:

Higher risk linked to:

Urban upbringing (larger cities).

Maternal complications during pregnancy and infections.

Childhood trauma and adversity.

Seasonality of birth (more likely born in winter/early spring).

Cognitive deficits can predict impending psychosis.

Option A: Being born in a rural area is not associated; urban upbringing is more relevant.

Option B: Maternal malnutrition during pregnancy is correct; it is a recognized risk factor.

Option C: Living at high altitudes is not linked to schizophrenia risk.
Option D: High levels of physical activity are not a risk factor for schizophrenia

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Maternal malnutrition during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of developing schizophrenia

choices.text: Increased serotonin and decreased dopamine levels
Increased dopamine and decreased glutamate levels
Increased glutamate and decreased GABA levels

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter abnormalities are commonly observed in patients with schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Neurotransmitters and Receptors

  • Dopamine:
    • Excessive release linked to positive symptoms.
    • Increased synaptic dopamine content and synthesis capacity observed.
  • Glutamate and GABA:
    • Elevated glutamate and reduced GABA levels noted.
    • Loss of GABAergic neurons in some cases.
  • Receptor Alterations:
    • Decreased muscarinic and nicotinic receptors in certain brain regions.
    • NMDA receptors may be hypofunctional due to glutamate and dopamine excess.

Option A: Increased serotonin and decreased dopamine levels.

  • This statement is incorrect. While serotonin levels can be altered in schizophrenia, the more significant finding is increased dopamine levels.

Option B: Increased dopamine and decreased glutamate levels.

  • This statement is incorrect. Patients with schizophrenia show increased levels of glutamate, particularly in the prefrontal and medial temporal areas.

Option C: Increased glutamate and decreased GABA levels.

  • This statement is correct. Many studies indicate increased levels of glutamate and decreased levels of GABA, particularly in areas such as the hippocampus.

Option D: Normal levels of all neurotransmitters.

  • This statement is incorrect. Neurotransmitter levels are not normal in schizophrenia; significant alterations have been documented.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Increased glutamate and decreased GABA levels is observed in patients withs schizophrenia.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is implicated in the negative symptoms of schizophrenia, according to current hypotheses?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Acetylcholine is mentioned but not primarily associated with negative symptoms.
  • Option B: Glutamate is also discussed, but not specifically tied to negative symptoms in this context.
  • Option C: Correct; serotonin excess is proposed as a cause of both positive and negative symptoms.
  • Option D: GABA is associated with regulatory effects on dopamine but is not directly tied to negative symptoms.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Serotonin is implicated in the negative symptoms of schizophrenia

questions.text: How does the classic course of schizophrenia generally progress after the first psychotic episode?
questions.solution:
COURSE OF SCHIZOPHRENIA:

Premorbid Signs and Symptoms:

  • Exist before the disease process.
  • Patients often exhibit schizoid or schizotypal personalities (quiet, introverted).
  • Common behaviours include having few friends, avoiding social activities, and a focus on solitary interests.

Prodromal Phase:

  • May involve obsessive-compulsive behaviour.
  • Symptoms can include peculiar behaviour, abnormal affect, unusual speech, and strange perceptual experiences.
  • Symptoms often recognized only retrospectively.

Emergence of Symptoms:

  • Symptoms typically begin in adolescence.
  • Social or environmental changes (e.g., college, substance use, family loss) may trigger symptoms.
  • Prodromal syndrome can last a year or more before overt psychotic symptoms appear.

Duration and Course:

  • Characterized by exacerbations and remissions after the first psychotic episode.
  • Patients may recover and function normally for periods but often relapse.
  • Each relapse leads to further deterioration in baseline functioning.

Long-term Effects:

  • Positive symptoms generally decrease in severity over time.
  • Negative or deficit symptoms may increase in severity, leading to lifelong vulnerability to stress.

questions.text: Which of the following is a positive prognostic factor for schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Prognosis of Schizophrenia

  • Life Expectancy: Schizophrenia reduces life expectancy by up to 20%.
  • Mortality Rates: Higher mortality from accidents and natural causes than the general population.
  • Remission Rates: Vary from 10% to 60%; estimated 20-30% can lead somewhat normal lives.
  • Long-term Outcomes:
    • 20-30% experience moderate symptoms.
    • 40-60% remain significantly impaired for life.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Prognostic Indicators

questions.text: Which of the following describes a common affective symptom in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Anhedonia is the inability to experience pleasure from activities typically enjoyable, often linked to depression and schizophrenia, leading to decreased interest in social interactions.

CLINICAL PRESENTATION OF SCHIZOPHRENIA


KEY TAKEAWAYS: Symptom Groupings:

choices.text: To monitor insulin metabolism and weight

questions.text: Why is health monitoring essential for patients on second-generation antipsychotics?
questions.solution:
Second-generation antipsychotics can affect insulin metabolism, necessitating monitoring of BMI, fasting blood glucose, and lipid profiles.

Side Effects of Antipsychotics

First-Generation Antipsychotics:

  • Commonly cause extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) such as:
    • Parkinsonism
    • Dystonias
    • Akathisia
  • Sedation and Postural Hypotension: Common with low-potency first-generation drugs, particularly during initial dosing.
  • Hyperprolactinemia: Elevated prolactin levels can lead to side effects like galactorrhea, irregular menses, and potential bone density loss.

Second-Generation Antipsychotics:

  • Less likely to cause EPS but can lead to weight gain and metabolic issues.

Option A : Tardive Dyskinesia (TD): Incorrect: TD involves involuntary, repetitive movements often affecting the face, lips, and limbs. Common symptoms include lip smacking, tongue thrusting, grimacing, blinking, and finger movements.

Primarily caused by long-term antipsychotic use, due to dopamine receptor hypersensitivity.

Option B and D are incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Health Monitoring

Essential for Patients on Second-Generation Antipsychotics:

  • Monitor BMI, fasting blood glucose, and lipid profiles regularly.
  • Weigh patients and calculate BMIs for at least six months after any medication change.

questions.text: What is the recommended duration of antipsychotic maintenance treatment after a first episode of psychosis?
questions.solution:
Patients experiencing their first episode of psychosis should be maintained on antipsychotics for at least one year to reduce the risk of relapse.

TREATMENT PHASES OF SCHIZOPHRENIA

i. Acute Phase Treatment

  • Duration: Typically lasts 4 to 8 weeks.
  • Mainstay of Treatment:
    • Antipsychotic medications are essential for managing acute psychotic symptoms.
  • First-Line Choice:
    • Second-generation antipsychotics are generally recommended due to their broader efficacy and more favourable side effect profiles compared to first-generation antipsychotics.

ii. Management of Agitation

  • Treatment Options:
    • Antipsychotics and benzodiazepines can effectively reduce agitation.
    • Intramuscular administration of antipsychotics provides quicker results for highly agitated patients.

iii. Benzodiazepines:

  • Lorazepam is effective and can be given orally or intramuscularly, potentially reducing the needed dosage of antipsychotics.

Maintenance Phase

  • Goal:
    • Prevent psychotic relapse and assist in improving functional outcomes.
  • Duration of Treatment:
    • Patients experiencing a first episode should be maintained on medication for at least one year.
    • For patients with two or more episodes, indefinite treatment is often recommended to minimize relapse risk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with persistent beliefs that she is being watched and followed by a group of individuals. These beliefs have lasted for over a year and have not improved despite reassurance from family and friends. She has no history of significant mood disturbances or hallucinations unrelated to her delusions. While her social interactions have declined due to her beliefs, her functioning in her job remains intact. Which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with her symptoms?
questions.solution:
DELUSIONAL DISORDER

  • Presence of one or more delusions lasting 1 month or longer.
  • Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met; any hallucinations are minor and linked to the delusion.
  • Functioning is not significantly impaired; behaviour is not notably bizarre or odd.
  • If manic or major depressive episodes occur, they are brief compared to the delusional periods.
  • Symptoms are not due to substance effects or another medical condition, nor better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., body dysmorphic or OCD).

Option B: Brief Psychotic Disorder

This disorder requires the presence of one or more psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc.) lasting at least one day but less than a month, with full return to premorbid functioning. In this case, the woman has experienced her delusions for over a year, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

Option C: Schizophreniform Disorder

Schizophreniform disorder involves similar symptoms as schizophrenia but lasts for at least one month and less than six months. However, the patient has had her delusions for more than a year, which exceeds the time frame necessary for this diagnosis.

Option D: Schizophrenia

Schizophrenia requires the presence of two or more active-phase symptoms for a significant portion of time over at least six months, with at least one being delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech. While the patient does have a delusion, the duration of her symptoms (over a year) does not meet the time criteria for schizophrenia, which necessitates continuous signs for at least six months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his family after they noticed he has been behaving strangely for several weeks. He reports hearing voices that tell him he is being persecuted and that he is the subject of a conspiracy. His speech is disorganized, making it difficult for him to maintain a conversation. He has withdrawn from social activities and is struggling to keep up with work. This episode has lasted for two months. Which diagnosis best fits his presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schizophrenia

Schizophrenia is characterized by two or more active-phase symptoms, including delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, or negative symptoms, persisting for at least six months. Although the patient exhibits several symptoms, his current episode has only lasted for two months, which does not meet the duration criterion for schizophrenia.

Option B: Schizoaffective Disorder

This disorder involves a major mood episode (depressive or manic) concurrent with symptoms of schizophrenia. The case does not indicate any significant mood disturbances accompanying his psychotic symptoms, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

Option C: Schizophreniform Disorder

Schizophreniform disorder includes symptoms similar to schizophrenia but lasts for at least one month but less than six months. Given that the patient has been experiencing symptoms for two months, this diagnosis aligns with the duration and symptom criteria.

Option D: Brief Psychotic Disorder

Brief psychotic disorder involves the presence of one or more psychotic symptoms lasting at least one day but less than a month, with a full return to premorbid functioning. The patient's symptoms have persisted for two months, exceeding the time frame necessary for this diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

choices.text: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with symptoms of depression, including feelings of hopelessness and a lack of interest in previously enjoyed activities. He also reports experiencing auditory hallucinations where he hears his deceased father speaking to him. His mood symptoms have been present for most of the past year, but he has had episodes of hallucinations without mood symptoms lasting for two weeks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schizophrenia

Schizophrenia involves active-phase symptoms persisting for six months, without a significant mood episode. Although the patient has hallucinations, his predominant mood symptoms do not fit this diagnosis.

Option B: Schizoaffective Disorder

Schizoaffective disorder involves a major mood episode concurrent with schizophrenia symptoms, along with periods of hallucinations without mood symptoms. The patient's combination of mood and psychotic symptoms makes this diagnosis appropriate.

Option C: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

This diagnosis requires the presence of major depressive symptoms alongside psychotic features. The patient has depression, but his hallucinations occurred without concurrent major depressive episodes, thus ruling this out.

Option D: Brief Psychotic Disorder

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting less than a month. The patient's symptoms have been present for a longer duration, making this diagnosis incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Schizoaffective Disorder

  • An uninterrupted period where there is a major mood episode (major depressive or manic) concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia.
  • Delusions or hallucinations present for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode at any time during the illness.
  • Symptoms meeting criteria for a major mood episode must be present for the majority of the illnesses active and residual phases.
  • The disturbance must not be due to the effects of a substance (e.g., drugs, medications) or another medical condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his friends after exhibiting unusually high energy levels, talking excessively, and engaging in risky behaviours such as reckless driving and overspending. He reports feeling "invincible" and has not slept for three nights. His friends mention that he has previously experienced episodes of severe depression but is currently in a highly euphoric state. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Bipolar I Disorder

Bipolar I disorder is characterized by at least one manic episode. The patient's symptoms of elevated mood, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, and risky behaviours align with the criteria for a manic episode, confirming this diagnosis.

Option B: Bipolar II Disorder

Bipolar II disorder requires the presence of at least one hypomanic episode and one major depressive episode, but not a full manic episode. Since the patient is experiencing manic symptoms, this diagnosis is not applicable.

Option C: Major Depressive Disorder

While the patient has a history of depression, he is currently in a manic state. Major depressive disorder would not account for the manic symptoms observed, thus making this diagnosis inappropriate.

Option D: Brief Psychotic Disorder

Brief psychotic disorder involves the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms lasting less than a month, with no clear manic or depressive episodes. The presence of a manic episode in this case rules this diagnosis out.

KEY TAKLEAWAYS:

Bipolar I Disorder

  • Diagnosis Criteria: At least one manic episode must be present
  • Exclusion Criteria:
    • The manic and major depressive episodes cannot be better explained by:
    • Schizoaffective disorder.
    • Schizophrenia
    • Schizophreniform disorder.
    • Delusional disorder.
    • Other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

Bipolar II Disorder

  • Diagnosis Criteria: At least one hypomanic episode (Criteria A-F).
    • At least one major depressive episode (Criteria A-C).
  • Exclusion Criteria:
    • There has never been a manic episode.
    • The hypomanic and major depressive episodes cannot be better explained by:
    • Schizoaffective disorder.
    • Schizophrenia
    • Schizophreniform disorder.
    • Delusional disorder.
    • Other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman visits her primary care physician, expressing feelings of sadness and lack of motivation that have persisted for more than two years. She mentions that her mood is low most days, and she often feels hopeless and fatigued. Her appetite has decreased, and she struggles to concentrate at work. She has never experienced a manic or hypomanic episode. Based on this information, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Major Depressive Disorder


However, the patient has experienced symptoms for over two years without meeting the criteria for a major depressive episode during that time, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Option B: Persistent Depressive Disorder/ Dysthymia

This diagnosis fits the patient's symptoms perfectly. She has a depressed mood for most of the day, more days than not, for over two years, and experiences additional symptoms like low energy and feelings of hopelessness. She has not had any episodes of mania or hypomania, confirming this diagnosis.

Option C: Bipolar Disorder

Bipolar disorder requires at least one manic or hypomanic episode. The patient explicitly states that she has never experienced these episodes. Therefore, this diagnosis is inappropriate given her history and current symptoms.

Option D: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood

Adjustment disorder is typically in response to a specific stressor and occurs within three months of that stressor. The patient's symptoms have been ongoing for over two years, making this diagnosis unsuitable.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: DSM CRITERIA FOR DYSTHYMIA:

  • Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.
  • Presence, while depressed, of two (or more)of the following:
  1. Poor appetite or overeating.
  2. Insomnia or hypersomnia.
  3. Low energy or fatigue.
  4. Low self-esteem.
  5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions.
  6. Feelings of hopelessness
  • During the 2-year period (1 year for children or adolescents) of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symp-toms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.
  • There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.
  • The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or others specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.
  • The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g., hypothyroidism).
  • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

choices.text: The individual shows psychotic symptoms that align with depressive themes
There is a marked decrease in sleep and a high level of energy
Mood brightens in response to positive events, with symptoms like weight gain and hypersomnia
The presence of severe agitation and distinct despair

questions.text: What is the feature of Atypical depression?
questions.solution:
A form of depression that responds to positive events (mood reactivity), contrasting with typical depression.

KEY SYMPTOMS:

  • Mood reactivity: Temporary improvement in mood in response to positive events.
  • Increased appetite or weight gain (often craving carbohydrates).
  • Hypersomnia: Excessive sleeping or prolonged nighttime sleep.
  • Leaden paralysis: Feeling of heavy limbs, often described as a sensation of being weighed down.
  • Sensitivity to rejection: High sensitivity to interpersonal rejection, impacting social and work life.

Option A: Incorrect. Psychotic features are associated with different specifiers, not atypical features.

Option B: Incorrect. This description fits manic features rather than atypical features.

Option C: Correct. "With atypical features" includes mood reactivity and symptoms like increased appetite and hypersomnia.

Option D: Incorrect. Severe agitation and distinct despair are more related to melancholic features, not atypical features. Melancholic depression, also known as melancholia, is a severe type of depression that can be more difficult to treat than other types of depression:

  • Symptoms: include loss of interest in activities, feelings of hopelessness, and thoughts of suicide. Other symptoms include:
    • Slowed speech, thoughts, and movements
    • Flat mood
    • Little emotional expression or response
    • Loss of appetite and weight
    • Poor sleep
    • Waking up early in the morning
    • Difficulty concentrating and remembering things
    • Strong feelings of guilt

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Depression With Atypical Features

Criteria: Mood reactivity (brightening in response to positive events) with two or more of:

  1. Significant weight gain or increased appetite.
  2. Hypersomnia.
  3. Leaden paralysis (heavy limbs).
  4. Interpersonal rejection sensitivity.

choices.text: LAIs guarantee complete adherence to treatment, eliminating the possibility of relapse
A test dose is recommended for all LAI formulations before starting treatment
Continuous treatment with LAIs has been shown to result in fewer relapses compared to oral antipsychotics
LAIs should only be prescribed to patients who have never taken oral antipsychotic medications

questions.text: Which of the following statements about long-acting injectable (LAI) antipsychotic medications is true?
questions.solution:
Option A: LAIs guarantee complete adherence to treatment, eliminating the possibility of relapse.

  • This statement is incorrect. While LAIs help improve adherence and can signal potential non-adherence, they do not ensure complete adherence or prevent relapse entirely.

Option B: A test dose is recommended for all LAI formulations before starting treatment.

  • This is false. A test dose is specifically recommended for LAI first-generation antipsychotics (FGAs) due to their higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), but not necessarily for second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs) where the risk is lower.

Option C: Continuous treatment with LAIs has been shown to result in fewer relapses compared to oral antipsychotics.

  • This is true. Observational studies indicate that continued treatment with LAIs is associated with fewer relapses and rehospitalizations compared to oral treatments.

Option D: LAIs should only be prescribed to patients who have never taken oral antipsychotic medications.

  • This statement is incorrect. LAIs can be prescribed after assessing tolerability through oral medications, and it's not a requirement that patients be antipsychotic-naïve.

Antipsychotic Depots/Long-Acting Injections (LAIs)

  • Effectiveness: LAIs may reduce relapses and rehospitalizations compared to oral medications, but evidence is mixed on their overall superiority.
  • Monitoring Adherence: LAIs allow for better monitoring of patient adherence, helping to identify potential relapses early.
  • Dosing Recommendations:
  • Start with the lowest therapeutic dose due to uncertain dose-response relationships.
  • Administer at the longest licensed intervals to minimize discomfort.
  • Adjust doses only after adequate assessment, as peak plasma levels take time to stabilize.
  • First-Episode Patients: Tolerability should ideally be established using oral medications before prescribing LAIs.
  • Test Doses: Recommended for LAI FGAs to assess sensitivity; not usually needed for SGAs.
